articles.headline: Immigrants Take to U.S. Streets in Show of Strength
articles.snippet: Originally billed as an economic boycott, the day evolved into a round of protests intended to influence Congress.
articles.abstract: Originally billed as an economic boycott, the day evolved into a round of protests intended to influence Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, May 1 — Hundreds of thousands of immigrants and their supporters skipped work, school and shopping on Monday and marched in dozens of cities from coast to coast.

articles.headline: Not WB Nor UPN
articles.snippet: The new CW network is making programming decisions that will be crucial to attracting its prime audience of teenagers and young adults.
articles.abstract: The new CW network is making programming decisions that will be crucial to attracting its prime audience of teenagers and young adults.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only two months after announcing the start-up of the CW network — the result of a merger in January of two struggling part-time networks, WB and UPN — executives from CBS and Warner Brothers met with the marketing department of their new entity, expecting to make a radical change.

articles.headline: In Senate Race, Pork Is Portrayed as Bad Politics
articles.snippet: In Nebraska and other states, challengers are trying to portray incumbents' pet projects as waste.
articles.abstract: In Nebraska and other states, challengers are trying to portray incumbents' pet projects as waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA, April 26 — In some other year, Pete Ricketts, a wealthy former Ameritrade executive who wants to replace Ben Nelson in the United States Senate, would probably not have considered mentioning all the items Mr. Nelson and his colleagues in Washington have helped bring home to Nebraska: financing for a parking garage at the private Creighton University, for instance, or for a parking lot at the Joslyn Art Museum here.

articles.headline: How Bad Is Inflation in Zimbabwe?
articles.snippet: Prices have increased 900%, with toilet paper costing $417 per sheet at one supermarket.
articles.abstract: Prices have increased 900%, with toilet paper costing $417 per sheet at one supermarket.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Microsoft and Google Set to Wage Arms Race
articles.snippet: The rivalry between the companies is growing more combative as the outcome is likely to shape the future of competition in computing and the way people use information technology.
articles.abstract: The rivalry between the companies is growing more combative as the outcome is likely to shape the future of competition in computing and the way people use information technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, described Google in an interview late last year as a worthy adversary, a company to test Microsoft's mettle. "This is hypercompetition, make no mistake," Mr. Gates observed.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Saul Hansell

articles.headline: Pensions in Peril Over Church Exemptions
articles.snippet: Under a little-known aspect of pension law, churches can opt out of the costly rules that apply to secular employers.
articles.abstract: Under a little-known aspect of pension law, churches can opt out of the costly rules that apply to secular employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mary Petti worked for 35 years at a community hospital in Orange, N.J., earning a pension with a government guarantee. But now the hospital has closed, money is leaking out of the plan, and Ms. Petti fears the funds will be exhausted by the time she plans to retire in five years. The government guarantee has vanished as well.

articles.headline: Nowadays, It's All Yours, Mine or Ours
articles.snippet: Madison Avenue has become obsessed with using the word "my" in advertising slogans, as well as in the names of brands, products and even a new television network.
articles.abstract: Madison Avenue has become obsessed with using the word "my" in advertising slogans, as well as in the names of brands, products and even a new television network.
articles.lead_paragraph: My, my, my.

articles.headline: Ideals Collide as Vatican Rethinks Condom Ban
articles.snippet: A clash is shaping up at the Vatican between the church's condom ban and its advocacy of human life.
articles.abstract: A clash is shaping up at the Vatican between the church's condom ban and its advocacy of human life.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, May 1 — Even at the Vatican, not all sacred beliefs are absolute: Thou shalt not kill, but war can be just. Now, behind the quiet walls, a clash is shaping up involving two poles of near certainty: the church's long-held ban on condoms and its advocacy of human life.

articles.headline: Taiwan Maker of Cellphones for Others Is Venturing Out on Its Own
articles.snippet: BenQ formed an intercontinental venture with Siemens so it could sell its own branded phones beyond Taiwan and China, placing it in competition with some of its former clients.
articles.abstract: BenQ formed an intercontinental venture with Siemens so it could sell its own branded phones beyond Taiwan and China, placing it in competition with some of its former clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Sheaffer Lee, president of the BenQ Corporation, loves to show off his company's mobile handsets. His favorite is the EF81, a slim, rectangular folding phone with a black metallic back and a gold-plated front embellished with calligraphy from a well-known Tang dynasty poem.

articles.headline: Spending Pushes Up Inflation
articles.snippet: Robust spending on homes, cars and other consumer goods kept the economy moving at a brisk pace and sent a critical measure of inflation higher in March.
articles.abstract: Robust spending on homes, cars and other consumer goods kept the economy moving at a brisk pace and sent a critical measure of inflation higher in March.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robust spending on homes, cars and other consumer goods kept the economy moving at a brisk pace and sent a critical measure of inflation higher in March, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, renewing concerns that the Federal Reserve will have to raise interest rates further.

articles.headline: Spending Pushes Up Inflation
articles.snippet: Robust spending on homes, cars and other consumer goods kept the economy moving at a brisk pace and sent a critical measure of inflation higher in March, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, renewing concerns that the Federal Reserve will h...
articles.abstract: Robust spending on homes, cars and other consumer goods kept the economy moving at a brisk pace and sent a critical measure of inflation higher in March, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, renewing concerns that the Federal Reserve will have to raise interest rates further.     Prices paid for consumer items excluding food and energy -- a gauge closely watched by policy makers -- rose at an annual pace of 2 percent in March, up from 1.8 percent in February, as personal spending, income and home construction all increased. Economists had expected prices to rise 1.9 percent. Including food and energy, prices rose 2.9 percent, the same pace as the month before.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robust spending on homes, cars and other consumer goods kept the economy moving at a brisk pace and sent a critical measure of inflation higher in March, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, renewing concerns that the Federal Reserve will have to raise interest rates further.

articles.headline: Ideals Collide as Vatican Rethinks Condom Ban
articles.snippet: Even at the Vatican, not all sacred beliefs are absolute: Thou shalt not kill, but war can be just. Now, behind the quiet walls, a clash is shaping up involving two poles of near certainty: the church's long-held ban on condoms and its advocacy of...
articles.abstract: Even at the Vatican, not all sacred beliefs are absolute: Thou shalt not kill, but war can be just. Now, behind the quiet walls, a clash is shaping up involving two poles of near certainty: the church's long-held ban on condoms and its advocacy of human life.      The issue is AIDS. Church officials recently confirmed that Pope Benedict XVI had requested a report on whether it might be acceptable for Catholics to use condoms in one narrow circumstance: to protect life inside a marriage when one partner is infected with H.I.V. or is sick with AIDS.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, May 1 - Even at the Vatican, not all sacred beliefs are absolute: Thou shalt not kill, but war can be just. Now, behind the quiet walls, a clash is shaping up involving two poles of near certainty: the church's long-held ban on condoms and its advocacy of human life.

articles.headline: Republicans Drop a Tax Plan After Businesses Protest
articles.snippet: Senate Republicans on Monday hurriedly abandoned a broad tax proposal opposed by the oil industry and business leaders, another sign of their struggle to come up with an acceptable political and legislative answer to high gasoline prices.     Sena...
articles.abstract: Senate Republicans on Monday hurriedly abandoned a broad tax proposal opposed by the oil industry and business leaders, another sign of their struggle to come up with an acceptable political and legislative answer to high gasoline prices.     Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, said he had decided to jettison the provision, which would have generated billions of dollars by changing the way businesses treat inventories for tax purposes. Instead, he said the Senate Finance Committee would hold hearings on the plan ''later this year, so the pluses and minuses of the provision can become well known.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 1 - Senate Republicans on Monday hurriedly abandoned a broad tax proposal opposed by the oil industry and business leaders, another sign of their struggle to come up with an acceptable political and legislative answer to high gasoline prices.

articles.headline: Immigrants Take to U.S. Streets in Show of Strength
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of immigrants and their supporters skipped work, school and shopping on Monday and marched in dozens of cities from coast to coast.      The demonstrations did not bring the nation to a halt as planned by some organizers, tho...
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of immigrants and their supporters skipped work, school and shopping on Monday and marched in dozens of cities from coast to coast.      The demonstrations did not bring the nation to a halt as planned by some organizers, though they did cause some disruptions and conveyed in peaceful but sometimes boisterous ways the resolve of those who favor loosening the country's laws on immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, May 1 - Hundreds of thousands of immigrants and their supporters skipped work, school and shopping on Monday and marched in dozens of cities from coast to coast.

articles.headline: States Challenge U.S. Over Truck Mileage
articles.snippet: Ten states, including California and New York, plan to file suit this week to force the Bush administration to toughen gasoline mileage regulations for sport utility vehicles and other trucks.      The suit contends that the administration did not...
articles.abstract: Ten states, including California and New York, plan to file suit this week to force the Bush administration to toughen gasoline mileage regulations for sport utility vehicles and other trucks.      The suit contends that the administration did not do a rigorous enough analysis of the environmental benefits of fuel economy regulations before issuing new rules last month.      Article, Page A21.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ten states, including California and New York, plan to file suit this week to force the Bush administration to toughen gasoline mileage regulations for sport utility vehicles and other trucks.

articles.headline: Nowadays, It's All Yours, Mine or Ours
articles.snippet: My, my, my.     Madison Avenue has become obsessed with using the word ''my'' -- along with ''your'' and ''our'' -- in advertising slogans, as well as in the names of brands, products and even a new television network.
articles.abstract: My, my, my.     Madison Avenue has become obsessed with using the word ''my'' -- along with ''your'' and ''our'' -- in advertising slogans, as well as in the names of brands, products and even a new television network.
articles.lead_paragraph: My, my, my.

articles.headline: Taiwan Maker of Cellphones for Others Is Venturing Out on Its Own
articles.snippet: Sheaffer Lee, president of the BenQ Corporation, loves to show off his company's mobile handsets. His favorite is the EF81, a slim, rectangular folding phone with a black metallic back and a gold-plated front embellished with calligraphy from a we...
articles.abstract: Sheaffer Lee, president of the BenQ Corporation, loves to show off his company's mobile handsets. His favorite is the EF81, a slim, rectangular folding phone with a black metallic back and a gold-plated front embellished with calligraphy from a well-known Tang dynasty poem.     The phone is one of Mr. Lee's favorites, not just because of its styling but also because it symbolizes the relationship between his company, one of Taiwan's largest electronics makers, and Siemens of Germany, which paid BenQ to take over its ailing handset division last year. Designed in Germany and Taiwan and built in Europe, the limited-edition phone, he says, aims to blend the passion of the East with the rationality of the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan - Sheaffer Lee, president of the BenQ Corporation, loves to show off his company's mobile handsets. His favorite is the EF81, a slim, rectangular folding phone with a black metallic back and a gold-plated front embellished with calligraphy from a well-known Tang dynasty poem.

articles.headline: Microsoft and Google Set to Wage Arms Race
articles.snippet: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, described Google in an interview late last year as a worthy adversary, a company to test Microsoft's mettle. ''This is hypercompetition, make no mistake,'' Mr. Gates observed.      The rivalry between the com...
articles.abstract: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, described Google in an interview late last year as a worthy adversary, a company to test Microsoft's mettle. ''This is hypercompetition, make no mistake,'' Mr. Gates observed.      The rivalry between the companies is growing more combative, and with good reason: the outcome is likely to shape the future of competition in computing and the way people use information technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, described Google in an interview late last year as a worthy adversary, a company to test Microsoft's mettle. "This is hypercompetition, make no mistake," Mr. Gates observed.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Saul Hansell

articles.headline: Not WB Nor UPN
articles.snippet: Only two months after announcing the start-up of the CW network -- the result of a merger in January of two struggling part-time networks, WB and UPN -- executives from CBS and Warner Brothers met with the marketing department of their new entity,...
articles.abstract: Only two months after announcing the start-up of the CW network -- the result of a merger in January of two struggling part-time networks, WB and UPN -- executives from CBS and Warner Brothers met with the marketing department of their new entity, expecting to make a radical change.     ''We walked into that meeting ready to throw out the name CW,'' said Barry Meyer, the chairman of Warner Brothers. ''We'd gotten so much grief from everybody. What does it mean? What is it?''
articles.lead_paragraph: Only two months after announcing the start-up of the CW network -- the result of a merger in January of two struggling part-time networks, WB and UPN -- executives from CBS and Warner Brothers met with the marketing department of their new entity, expecting to make a radical change.

articles.headline: How Bad Is Inflation in Zimbabwe?
articles.snippet: How bad is inflation in Zimbabwe? Well, consider this: at a supermarket near the center of this tatterdemalion capital, toilet paper costs $417.     No, not per roll. Four hundred seventeen Zimbabwean dollars is the value of a single two-ply sheet...
articles.abstract: How bad is inflation in Zimbabwe? Well, consider this: at a supermarket near the center of this tatterdemalion capital, toilet paper costs $417.     No, not per roll. Four hundred seventeen Zimbabwean dollars is the value of a single two-ply sheet. A roll costs $145,750 -- in American currency, about 69 cents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: In Senate Race, Pork Is Portrayed as Bad Politics
articles.snippet: In some other year, Pete Ricketts, a wealthy former Ameritrade executive who wants to replace Ben Nelson in the United States Senate, would probably not have considered mentioning all the items Mr. Nelson and his colleagues in Washington have help...
articles.abstract: In some other year, Pete Ricketts, a wealthy former Ameritrade executive who wants to replace Ben Nelson in the United States Senate, would probably not have considered mentioning all the items Mr. Nelson and his colleagues in Washington have helped bring home to Nebraska: financing for a parking garage at the private Creighton University, for instance, or for a parking lot at the Joslyn Art Museum here.     Those would be left for Senator Nelson, a Democrat, to boast about.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA, April 26 - In some other year, Pete Ricketts, a wealthy former Ameritrade executive who wants to replace Ben Nelson in the United States Senate, would probably not have considered mentioning all the items Mr. Nelson and his colleagues in Washington have helped bring home to Nebraska: financing for a parking garage at the private Creighton University, for instance, or for a parking lot at the Joslyn Art Museum here.

articles.headline: Pensions in Peril Over Church Exemptions
articles.snippet: Mary Petti worked for 35 years at a community hospital in Orange, N.J., earning a pension with a government guarantee. But now the hospital has closed, money is leaking out of the plan, and Ms. Petti fears the funds will be exhausted by the time s...
articles.abstract: Mary Petti worked for 35 years at a community hospital in Orange, N.J., earning a pension with a government guarantee. But now the hospital has closed, money is leaking out of the plan, and Ms. Petti fears the funds will be exhausted by the time she plans to retire in five years. The government guarantee has vanished as well.      Her plight illustrates a little-known aspect of pension law, which allows churches and organizations affiliated with them to escape the costly and complicated rules that apply to secular employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mary Petti worked for 35 years at a community hospital in Orange, N.J., earning a pension with a government guarantee. But now the hospital has closed, money is leaking out of the plan, and Ms. Petti fears the funds will be exhausted by the time she plans to retire in five years. The government guarantee has vanished as well.
